content:
The Thunderbird email client is only available for desktop Windows, macOS, Linux and as a mobile version for Android.

They are looking for developers to work on a mobile version for iOS/iPadOS as per https://blog.thunderbird.net/2025/01/video-the-thunderbird-mobile-team/

There is no Thunderbird Accounts though there is Mozilla Accounts (formerly called Firefox Accounts til Nov 2023), however it not used with with the Thunderbird email client. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/access-mozilla-services-firefox-account
creator: James

content: Díky za reakci. Nastavení změnu sloupců ve složkách archívu zpráv, včetně možnosti změny ve všech již dříve vytvořených, lze takto upravit. To znám. Můj problém je však v tom, že při vytvoření nové složky v archívu se mně vždy v nové složce zobrazí někde přednastavené sloupce, z nichž mně většina nevyhovuje. A tak musím pokaždé u nové složky měnit zobrazené sloupce, jejich pořadí a podle kterého sloupce se mají zprávy v nové složce řadit. Bohužel mám rád strukturované informace a tak nové složky vytvářím často. Rád bych měl v každé nově vytvořené složce archivu zpráv automaticky jen ty sloupce, které mně vyhovují a nemuset je pokaždé měnit.

content: 102 was a stable release. Ignore any reference to 103, as that was not an official release. For your protection, I encourage going to settings>general and verify that no update happens without your approval. That is, you do NOT want automatic update. I also suggest creating a backup of your profile - I do this myself for all major upgrades. one way to do that is to: - exit thunderbird - at windows desktop, enter %appdata% in the search bar and press enter key. That should open file explorer at the username\appdata\roaming directory. - highlight the thunderbird folder and copy it to another place on computer or to external media.
creator: davidsk

content: David Thanks very much , that sounds a sensible thing to do and put the backup on external media. I assume the folder you mentioned contains all the necessary reload data should a failure occur. I will wait and see if any further information arrives before trying it just in case I open a bag of worms on compatibility. Regards A
creator: not.6770

content:
here is the info in brief steps:

BACKUP

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media

RESTORE

  1. ensure thunderbird is installed and NOT running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  4. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content: It could be any number of reasons. One thing to check is to verify that the email address in incoming pane is the same as the email address in SMTP server pane. This problem is not uncommon when a user has multiple email accounts with the same provider and has the SMTP server settings crossed.

creator: cgille

content:
cgille said
The mail server responded: Abusive Pattern Detected (ZD/78B9EF1).

That message is from your mail providers mail server. Thunderbird is just the delivery mechanism reporting what the provider gave it to explain why sending failed.

You do not name the mail provider that is giving the error, so guessing is all anyone can do. The actual error code does not appear in a Google search, which is unusual. I am sure your provider will be rejecting mail from more than just you, unless it is a hosted domain and you have subscribed for something special, or you are breaching the providers terms of service.

Are you sure the from address domain (the bit after the @) is also operated by the outgoing server you are attempting to use to send mail. ie if your address is Gill@brown.name, then the SMTP server being used should be one registered in DNS as supporting Brown.name so sending from say Spectrum's SMTP server will cause issues.

The only thing I can find that is similar is with Microsoft/Outlook/Office365 See https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-office-365/outbound-spam-protection-about

content:
To enter a code block, surround it with preformat tags: 

<pre>code
</pre>


Click the Preview Reply button to see the effect.

Don't precede paragraphs with a space, as it makes the text unwrapped in the resulting display.

content:
This worked: The `inbox.msf` file is typically associated with Mozilla Thunderbird, an email client. It serves as an index file for the emails in your inbox. On Windows 11, you can usually find it in the Thunderbird profile folder. To locate it:

1. Close Thunderbird 2. Press Windows + R to open the Run dialog box. 3. Type %APPDATA%\Thunderbird\Profiles and press Enter. 4. Open the folder with a name like `xxxxxxxx.default` (the `xxxxxxxx` part is a random string). 5. Navigate to the `Mail` or `ImapMail` folder, depending on your email setup. 6. Delete the inbox.msf file 7. Open Thunderbird. It will rebuilt the index and create a new inbox.msf file

This deleted all of the corrupted emails. So far, it's working fine.

You are looking at card view format. You are wanting table view.

You want the message list to look like https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/getting-started-thunderbird-main-window-supernova. You need to do the reverse of https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/getting-started-thunderbird-main-window-supernova#w_vertical-view-layout-with-card-view

Address book also has "list display options" icon, to switch between card view and table view
